elements.name: intro
elements.html:
Your Experience Teaching Code.org's Software Engineering and Computer Vision Module

Chapter 1: GitHub and Copilot || Lesson 2: Intro to GitHub

The purpose of this survey is to understand your experience and perceptions after teaching this lesson.

Let's get started!

elements.name: ch1_l2_st_connections_java_ides
elements.title: What percentage of students frequently made connections between AP CSA tools like Java Lab and skills and real-world applications during the lesson?

elements.name: ch1_l2_similarities_javalab_ides
elements.title: I was able to highlight features of Java Lab that were similar to professional IDEs (i.e., VS Code).

elements.name: ch1_l2_relevant_content
elements.title: I believe today's content was relevant to my students.

elements.name: ch1_l2_integrate_future_lessons
elements.title: I am considering integrating some of today's tools or resources into my future lessons.

elements.name: ch1_l2_usability
elements.title: I frequently faced challenges in integrating parts of today's lesson due to usability issues.

elements.name: ch1_l2_teaching_materials_effective
elements.title: The materials provided for this lesson were very effective in supporting my students' understanding.

elements.name: ch1_l2_overall_feedback
elements.title: Is there any area of this lesson you felt could have been improved or explained more thoroughly? Please provide any specific suggestions for improvement.

elements.name: survey_preamble_header_and_text
elements.html:
Welcome to Code.org's Software Engineering and Computer Vision's {survey_variable}

Code.org relies on surveys as a crucial tool to remain connected to teachers, and to give you the opportunity to provide feedback about your experience teaching our curriculum.

The purpose of this survey is to understand your experience teaching Code.org's Software Engineering and Computer Vision module to inform how it can be improved. 

Privacy and Confidentiality

  • Your individual responses here are completely confidential.
  • Your identity will never be revealed publicly or used to tie any responses back to you personally.
  • We may share de-identified, aggregate data (representing all responses) publicly.
  • Your de-identified responses will be used by Code.org to improve our curriculum and programs.

This survey should take less than 5 minutes to complete.  Your complete honesty and candor are appreciated.

elements.name: survey_preamble_header_and_text
elements.html:
Welcome to Code.org's Software Engineering and Computer Vision - Post-Module Teacher Survey

Code.org relies on surveys as a crucial tool to remain connected to teachers, and to give you the opportunity to provide feedback about your experience teaching our curriculum.

The purpose of this survey is to understand your experience teaching Code.org's Software Engineering and Computer Vision module to inform how it can be improved. 

Privacy and Confidentiality

  • Your individual responses here are completely confidential.
  • Your identity will never be revealed publicly or used to tie any responses back to you personally.
  • We may share de-identified, aggregate data (representing all responses) publicly.
  • Your de-identified responses will be used by Code.org to improve our curriculum and programs.

This survey should take less than 5 minutes to complete.  Your complete honesty and candor are appreciated.

elements.name: intro
elements.html:
Your Experience Teaching Code.org's Software Engineering and Computer Vision Module

The purpose of this survey is to understand your experience, perceptions, and your learning after teaching this module.

Let's get started!

elements.name: section_intro_coding_proficiency
elements.html: General Coding Proficiency

elements.name: st_articulate_coding_decisions
elements.title: After participating in this module, what percentage of students do you believe can effectively articulate their coding decisions and processes?

elements.name: effect_communication_matrix
elements.title: How impactful were each of the following on students' communication skills?

rows.text: Model training and integration in Java

elements.name: section_intro_real_world_tools
elements.html: Real World Tools

elements.name: javalab_ides_similarities
elements.title: After teaching this module, I can confidently identify similarities between Java Lab and professional IDEs (i.e., VS Code).

elements.name: confidence_ides
elements.title: Teaching this module significantly boosted my confidence in using professional IDEs (i.e., VS Code).

elements.name: additional_content_ai_assisted_coding
elements.title: Which of the following would be your FIRST CHOICE to improve or add to better guide students in AI-assisted coding?

choices.text: Introduction to AI tools and their relevance
Case studies showcasing real-world AI-assisted coding scenarios
Deep dives into common pitfalls and challenges
Guided peer review sessions on AI-generated solutions
Ethical considerations and responsible use of AI in coding
Comparing traditional coding with AI-assisted techniques

elements.name: ai_generated_code_critique_students
elements.title: How often did students critique AI-generated code during the module?

elements.name: ai_code_difficulties_matrix
elements.title: How often did you notice the following while students worked with AI-generated code?

rows.text: Over-reliance on AI suggestions without critical analysis
Difficulty in integrating AI-generated code with existing code
Uncertainty about the underlying logic or reasoning behind AI suggestions
Hesitation or resistance to using AI tools due to unfamiliarity or mistrust

elements.name: st_ability_adapt_ai_generated_code
elements.title: After completing this module, what percentage of students improved in their ability to adapt AI-generated code?

elements.name: section_ai_models_computer_vision
elements.html: AI Models and Computer Vision

elements.name: st_limitations_model_training
elements.title: After completing this module, what percentage of students effectively understand the limitations of model training?

elements.name: st_integrate_ai_into_java
elements.title: After completing this module, what percentage of students understand how to incorporate AI models in a Java program?

elements.name: section_teacher_confidence_new_cs_ai_concepts
elements.html: Teacher Confidence with New CS and AI Concepts

elements.name: frequency_use_ai_generated_examples
elements.title: How frequently did you utilize AI-generated examples while teaching this module?

elements.name: confidence_introducing_new_concepts
elements.title: I feel confident in introducing new CS and AI topics to my students.

elements.name: section_general_feedback
elements.html: General Feedback

elements.name: pacing
elements.title: The pacing outlined in the lesson plan worked for me.

elements.name: reason_didnt_finish
elements.title: Did you finish the module?

choices.text: No, I didn't have enough time.
No, it was too difficult to teach.
My students found it too difficult.

elements.name: survey_preamble_header_and_text
elements.html:
Welcome to Code.org's Software Engineering and Computer Vision - Pre-Module Teacher Survey

Code.org relies on surveys as a crucial tool to remain connected to teachers, and to give you the opportunity to provide feedback about your experience teaching our curriculum.

The purpose of this survey is to understand better who our teachers are, their motivation to teach Code.org's Software Engineering and Computer Vision module, and their previous experience with this content and tools. 

Privacy and Confidentiality

  • Your individual responses here are completely confidential.
  • Your identity will never be revealed publicly or used to tie any responses back to you personally.
  • We may share de-identified, aggregate data (representing all responses) publicly.
  • Your de-identified responses will be used by Code.org to improve our curriculum and programs.

This survey should take less than 5 minutes to complete.  Your complete honesty and candor are appreciated.

elements.name: section1_student_experience
elements.html:
Your Students

The purpose of this section of the survey is to understand how your students might benefit from the content of this module.

Let's get started!

elements.name: students_code_purpose
elements.title: Most students in my class typically articulate the purpose and functionality of their code effectively.

elements.name: explain_code_challenge
elements.title: What is the most common challenge students face in explaining their coding decisions and thought processes?

choices.text: Lack of confidence in their code

elements.name: students_relevance
elements.title: I anticipate that this module's content will be highly relevant for my students.

elements.name: section2_real_world_tools
elements.html:
Real World Tools

The purpose of this section of the survey is to understand your experience with Java Lab and professional integrated development environments (IDEs) like VS Code.

elements.name: javalab_comfort
elements.title: I am comfortable navigating and using features in Java Lab.

elements.name: professional_ides_comfort
elements.title: I am comfortable navigating and using features within a professional integrated development environment (IDE) like VS Code.

elements.name: section3_ai_generated_code
elements.html:
AI-Generated Code

The purpose of this section of the survey is to understand your experience and perceptions around AI-generated Code.

elements.name: ai_code_challenges_students
elements.title: What specific challenges do you anticipate students might have regarding their use of AI-generated code?

choices.text: They might rely too heavily on AI
Students might find it difficult to debug AI-generated code
Students might be overconfident in AI's accuracy

elements.name: ai_generated_code_experience_students
elements.title: To your knowledge, how often have your students previously interacted with or used code-generating AI tools in their assignments or projects?

elements.name: ai_generated_code_comfort_teacher
elements.title: I feel comfortable guiding students in using AI code-generating tools.

elements.name: ai_generated_code_beneficial_teacher
elements.title: I believe my students and I would benefit from using AI code-generating tools to generate real-world examples of Java concepts.

elements.name: section4_ai_models_computer_vision
elements.html:
AI Models and Computer Vision

The purpose of this section of the survey is to understand your familiarity with teaching AI models and Computer Vision.

elements.name: ai_models_understanding_students
elements.title: I believe my students have a strong understanding of how AI models are trained.

elements.name: ai_model_integration_familiarity_teacher
elements.title: I am familiar with integrating AI models into a Java program.

elements.name: ai_model_integration_teaching_experience_teacher
elements.title: Have you previously taught a lesson on incorporating AI models in any programming language?

choices.text: No, and I haven't considered it

elements.name: section5_teaching_context
elements.html:
Teaching Context

The purpose of this section of the survey is to understand our teachers' motivation to teach Code.org's Software Engineering and Computer Vision module, and their previous experience with this content and tools.

elements.name: confidence_teaching_content
elements.title: I feel confident to teach the content of this module to my students.

elements.name: confidence_teaching_new_cs_concepts
elements.title: I am comfortable introducing and discussing new CS and AI topics with my students.

elements.name: hesitant_new_cs_concepts
elements.title: Which CS or AI topics have you been hesitant to introduce in the classroom?

choices.text: Integration of AI in coding projects
Using professional IDEs in classroom settings

elements.name: frequency_update_lesson_plans
elements.title: How often do you update your lesson plans or materials to include new developments in the CS and AI fields?

elements.name: confidence_use_ai_teaching_practices
elements.title: I feel comfortable using AI tools as part of my teaching practices (i.e., to generate real-world examples to show to students, draft lesson plans or activities, brainstorm ways to differentiate content or provide extension activities, and/or demonstrate writing or debugging code).

elements.name: confidence_teaching_ai_tools
elements.title: I feel comfortable teaching students how to use the AI tools and resources used in this module (i.e., GitHub Copilot, Teachable Machine).
